revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=January 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Nigar Nazar | image = Nigar_Nazar_1.jpg | imagesize = | alt = Nigar Nazar | caption = Nigar Nazar | birth_place = [[Karachi]]
| field = Cartoonist | nationality = Pakistani | works = Gogi (cartoon) | website = {{URL|www.gogistudios.com}} }}
'''Nigar Nazar''' (born 1953) is the first [[Pakistani]] female [[cartoonist]].<ref name=dawn/> Her character Gogi is an urban Pakistani woman struggling with her frailties in the context of [[Gender discrimination|sexist]] [[social norm]]s.<ref name=dawn/> She is the chief executive officer of Gogi Studios. Between 2002 and 2003, she was a [[Fulbright Program|Fulbright Professor]] at the art department of the [[University of Oregon]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://prideofpakistan.com/detail-who-is-who.php?name=NigarNazar&id=394|title=Nigar Nazar {{!}} Pride of Pakistan {{!}} Film & TV {{!}} PrideOfPakistan.com|website=prideofpakistan.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-28}}</ref>
==Biography== Nigar changed her degree from medical to fine arts in 1968. Her cartoon Gogi appeared for the first time in 1970 in [[Karachi]]'s Institute of Arts and Crafts annual magazine.<ref name=dawn/> She graduated in fine arts from the [[University of the Punjab]], [[Lahore]].<ref name=fp/> She also attended courses at the [[Australian National University]], [[Canberra]].<ref name=fp/>
In 2002–2003, she was a Fulbright scholar at [[University of Oregon]] art department, and in 2009, she was a Fulbright Visiting Specialist at [[Colorado College]].<ref name=u-co/> She attended a [[UNICEF]]-sponsored training session on animated film at [[Hanna-Barbera Studios]] in [[Manila]].<ref name=tapestry/>
Gogi Studios works on projects that actively address [[social issues]].<ref name=dawn/> In 2009, Nazar completed five "awareness comics on burning social issues such as extremism, corruption, sectarian violence, girls education and women rights".<ref name=dawn/> Three books which are a compilation of her cartoons have been published, as well as several calendars, brochures, diaries, and posters.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} In collaboration with [[non-governmental organization|non-governmental organisations]]s, 12 [[public transport|public-transport]] buses were wrapped with Gogi cartoons in 2004 to convey social messages.<ref name=et-aware/> She has produced for various international NGOs three books for children on health and [[hygiene]], the [[Environmental quality|environment]], [[disaster management]], [[first aid]], and [[child safety]].
Now living in [[Islamabad]], Nazar says, "My work ... started from newspaper and reached the community, as it appeared on public buses and hospitals. I published books and comics and the aim of my studio is to address mindset for a positive change."<ref name=gogi-power/>
She is a founding member of the [[Asian Youth Association for Animators and Cartoonists]], headquartered in [[Guiyang]], [[China]].<ref name=dawn/> She has been an official speaker and jury member of numerous art and cartoon competitions, both international and national such as the [[APACA]] ([[AYAAC]]), [[Aydin Dogan Vakfi]] (Turkey), [[Himal Cartoon Conference]] ([[Nepal]]), [[Cartoonists Congress]] ([[Malaysia]]/Singapore), and the [[Oxfam]] Congress for Women's Issues ([[Sri Lanka]]). Nazar has conducted many workshops and outreach programs for privileged and underprivileged students in Pakistan.
===Gogi=== Nazar's main cartoon character, Gogi, has been a popular comicstrip in newspapers worldwide. Gogi depicts a modern Pakistani Muslim woman with short hair, long eyelashes and a [[polka dot]] dress.<ref name=lpj/> Asked in an interview to describe Gogi, Nazar said, "In the words of a university student who has done a well-researched thesis on my work, 'Gogi is the symbol of womanhood in Pakistan, with all her adventures and escapades in daily life, facing day to day hypocrisies in a male dominated society "<ref name=ceo-intv/> The ''Denver Post'' described Gogi as "a bit like '[[Blondie (comic strip)|Blondie]]' and a bit like [[Oprah Winfrey|Oprah]]—except devoutly Muslim".<ref name=post-nazar/>
[[Image:Nigar Nazar 2.jpg|thumb|alt=Nigar Nazar|Nazar painting the portrait ''Father of the nation, Quaid-e-Azam'' on [[National Day]] celebrations for the Pakistan Embassy in England, 1986. That painting is still present in the Pakistan consulate, Bradford]]
==Honours== Nigar was featured in the [[Wateen Telecom Pakistan]] "Icon 2010 of Pakistan" calendar.<ref name=shares-exp/> The [[Cartoonists Rights Network]] named her first among innovative users of cartoons.<ref name=shares-exp/> She received the [[Mohtarma Fatima Jinnah Award]] from the government of Pakistan.<ref name=dt-docu/> She received the Booruker [[UNESCO]] prize in 1997 for her work at an [[orphanage]] in Kyrgyzstan.<ref name=star-career/> [[BBC]] nominated her for Hundred influential Global women who brought about a difference in the world, she has been voted among "50 Power Women" nationally by The News (Daily news paper.)
== Projects == {{BLP unsourced section|date=July 2011}} ;[[Trauma counselling]] of earthquake victims through [[puppet]]s : Nigar devised Puppet Shows weaving elements of Trauma Counseling in the script for Earthquake victims (October 2005) Gogi comic strip characters entertained and conducted Trauma Counselling in an innovative and impactful way. ; Outreach Programs and lectures (January 2008 – December 2009) : Nazar conducted outreach programs in [[Islamabad]], [[Rawalpindi]] and [[Lahore]] on environmental subjects. She showed animated cartoons, demonstrated the art of drawing cartoons, interacted with children, and distributed free Gogi books and stationary in Gogi school bags to the attendees. ; Workshops (2008–2010) : Nazar conducted numerous cartooning workshops for children, especially those from disadvantaged communities, with the international non-governmental organisations PLAN, HEC [[(Higher Education Commission)]], National Government/CARE and Shaj-re-Ilm. Workshops were also organised with private organisations, such as KFC, for children. Cartooning workshop were conducted by Nigar Nazar for Karachi University, NUST and Gymkhana Lahore. Courses in drawing and cartooning were conducted in Fatimah Jinnah University.
==Publications== {{Biblio|date=July 2011}} {{Prose|section|date=July 2011}} * ''Glad to Meetcha Gogi'', Adam Publishers ([[Malta]]), 1975. * ''Gogi on the Go'', Pak-American Publishers, 1982. * ''Koorey ka Jin'' (English: ''The Garbage Monster''),including a [[board game]], 2005. * Prepared training modules for [[HIV/AIDS]], for [[UNICEF]], 2005. * Designed and authored a baby-record book published by [[Ferozsons Laboratories]] in 2006. * Prepared and illustrated two books on disaster management in 2006 (a JICA project). * Collection of comic strips ''Going Gogi'' published in 2009; later translated to Urdu. * January 2010: produced five comic books on life skills: girls' education, corruption, anti-recruitment, [[women's rights]], and [[sectarian violence]].

|archivedate = 29 September 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref> <ref name=fp>{{cite web | url = http://www.dailyfpost.com/Women%20Archives/wom-5/womenachiver.htm | title = From FP's Desk | date = 30 October 2006 | work = Financial Post | publisher = Qudsia Kahn }}</ref> <ref name=shares-exp>{{cite news | url = http://www.thenews.com.pk/TodaysPrintDetail.aspx?ID=51730&Cat=6 | title = Nigar Nazar shares her cartooning experience | last = Achakzai | first = Jamila | date = 10 June 2011 | newspaper = The News International | publisher = Jang Group | location = Karachi, Pakistan | accessdate = 17 July 2011 }}</ref> <ref name=ceo-intv>{{cite interview | last = Nazar | first = Nigar | interviewer = Siham Basir | date = 28 June 2010 | title = Interview: Nigar Nazar CEO, Gogi Studios | work = Newsline | url = http://www.newslinemagazine.com/2010/06/interview-nigar-nazar-ceo-gogi-studios/ | accessdate = 17 July 2011 }}</ref> <ref name=post-nazar>{{cite news | title = The Pioneer: Nigar Nazar, lecturing this month at Colorado College, has proved over 40 years that a cartoonist's pen is a mighty voice | last = Draper | first = Electa | newspaper = The Denver Post | location = Denver, CO | date = 17 October 2009 | page = B-01 }}</ref> <ref name=dt-docu>{{cite news | url = http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2008\03\26\story_26-3-2008_pg12_3 | title = Docu on first female cartoonist | newspaper = Daily Times | date = 26 March 2008 | accessdate = 17 July 2011 | publisher = Shehryar Taseer | location = Lahore, Pakistan }}</ref> <ref name=star-career>{{cite news | url =
